subtitle: Thinking Allowed, conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery, with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Emmy Vadnais, co-host
with Jeffrey Mishlove. Today we'll be exploring
Imaginal Cognition. My guest is Alan Steinfeld,
who is host and producer of New Realities
on New York City Cable and New Realities on his
YouTube channel. He has produced two feature-length
documentary films on UFOs and is a board member
of the Friends of the Institute of Noetic
Sciences. He is author of the anthology,
Making Contact, Preparing for the New Realities
of Extraterrestrial Existence, and Careers in Alternative Medicine. Alan is located in
the New York City area, and this is his second
interview on New Thinking Allowed. Now I'll
switch over to the internet video. Welcome, Alan. It's a pleasure to have you back with
us on New Thinking Allowed today. Thank you,
Emmy. I have to say this moment we took before
we started and you closed your eyes, I felt as if you brought me into a space. So thank
you for your emanation of consciousness because
I felt you. Oh, well, thank you, Alan. Yeah.
Where did that bring you into space? Well,
I felt you and I felt coming into your space
of quietness. And that's some of what I think
we can talk about today, how thoughts are
things. Consciousness is a field. It's transmittable.
It's becoming more and more obvious in science
and just spiritual terms that consciousness,
whatever that is on many levels, needs to
be examined as an application. You know, when
I interviewed Deepak Chopra, which I've done
20 times every time he has a new book, he says,
oh, would you like to interview me? I say, sure.
And so anyway, it's not just consciousness, yes,
is the ground of all being, but it's something we
can use and work with and understand and develop.
It's coming online as a tool, but it's also
everything else. So of course, when words come into a kind of cultural collective,
it evolves its search for meaning and it's still something that's finding its place,
that word, that framing. And so right now
it's vague and means so many different things,
which is great because many people need to
understand there's aspects of consciousness,
if it is the ground of all being, which I knew maybe, and Jeff probably think it is.
So that's a good kind of beginning. Initially,
you had suggested having this conversation to
explore really what is the mechanism of remote
viewing, non-local consciousness. And you and
I have heard many different theories and you wanted
to explore really, you know, how does that work?
Right, exactly. So I've been teaching remote
viewing for the last three or four years after
learning it from Russell Targ about 20 years
ago. And I want to know what's happening,
and even telepathy, I know you're intuitive.
So how do we receive sense information beyond
our five senses? How do we pick that up? Where's
that coming from? And I talked to the best remote
viewers. I've talked to Russell Targ. He didn't
have, for me, an adequate explanation. He's a
fantastic human being. He's great. He's probably
as advanced as anyone. I had a chance to have
lunch with Ingo Swann once, but we didn't really
talk about that. I think we talked about astrology.
And I also had a really in-depth interview with
Hal Puthoff, I said, and Hal said to me in the
interview, he went into SRI every day and saying,
this is impossible. It's impossible for someone to
get information that's not here, not local. And
every day he'd come and be surprised by what
happened at SRI. So I started to understand,
well, what's going on? How are we able... And
Paul Smith, I talked to recently at Contact in
the Desert. I asked, well, Paul, how does it work?
What's really going on? And there's no denying
that we can perceive non-locally. You talked
about peer review experiment. Well, we've had 40
years of peer review application. It's a fact.
Humans have the facility to perceive targets or
thoughts or situations, past, present, and future,
here, there, and everywhere with enough practice
and intention. I don't think there's a dispute
among people who've studied this. But how are we
perceiving that? It's not through the five senses,
which mainstream science says, that's all there is
to know. And what I say to mainstream science is,
let's say your computer, let's say you didn't
know about the internet, and you thought all
the information on your computer had to be programmed into your computer by something
and some hardware. And I come along and say, you
know what? I'm getting information that's not
programmed onto my computer because I have
a certain application that's open to receive
non-local information. It's sort of like that. Does that make sense?
It does. It does. Some people will even say that there isn't non-local consciousness,
that consciousness is everywhere.
It is everywhere. And it's also when I'm receiving
internet, it's localized through my computer from a
non-local source, because then anyone on the
internet can pretty much, if they're getting to
the website or wherever they're going, can access
that non-local information locally. So yes,
the receiver is local and consciousness, like
many people are saying, maybe is not contained
in the brain, but is received by the brain.
Right. And that is a theory of how the brain
functions, that it's a reducing valve for information from wherever it comes from.
Right. So I wanted to see if the brain is sort of like a radio that's receiving
a signal from somewhere, where's the antenna?
Where is that mechanism? So yes, if you open up
the radio, you're not going to find an announcer
in there or the Beatles playing their eternal
hits or something like that, but it's being
received. And if you were someone who was not
aware of technology, you would think, oh, there
must be something in, if you had that primitive
perspective, like a lot of Western scientists do,
you must think that consciousness is coming from
the brain and it's not receiving it. So I say,
this is just my theory and maybe other people,
that this mechanism, and of course, we'll talk
about the whole body is a receiver of consciousness,
of course, but what we're talking about is, and
maybe that's also old fashioned, the brain is
receiving the thought form realities from some
other realm or non-locally. But of course,
you also mentioned that every cell in our body
is receiving, you know, a feel. So the brain,
I feel there's the brain, the mind and
consciousness, right? The brain is the hardware,
the mind is sort of the software and consciousness,
what is consciousness? It's the operator. If you
have the hardware and software, the computer
just sits there. What you need is the operator
and the operator is consciousness. Otherwise you
just have computer sitting there doing nothing.
But so the application of the use of that takes
the conscious being, the conscious interaction
with the hardware and software. So taking that
to the next level, what is receiving that? How is
that working? What is the application of receiving
non-local consciousness? And we're really in the
early stages, like even the work of Dean Radin,
who's so brilliant talking about what consciousness
and his book, what's it called? Supernatural? Super...
Supernormal.
Yes. Supernormal. We're seeing that human beings, even your work as an intuitive,
we're so much more than we've been told by
the mainstream, by education, by religion, by
media. You know, we've been dumbed down to think that in a Western science model,
which is, it's so great what Jeffrey Mishlove
has done is really presented information that
goes beyond an old paradigm of who we are as human
beings. And then we can tap into this infinite
field that we just have to apply this intention.
So I try to understand how is it that when I do
remote viewing, I'm able to see, perceive
something that's non-local. Someone says they
have a target or someone's in this location.
Immediately, most of the time, I get an image.
I put my intention on something, on a target,
or even a little CRV code and something comes.
It's something, and it comes easier, I'm sure
you know, if you're out of the way, right?
Yeah. When we are less connected to trying to
receive the information or striving or connected
to thoughts or emotions that might be blurring,
dialing into that quote, radio signal,
that can be a barrier. But you're right, when
we get out of our own way, which is really,
I would say coming into, well, in Buddhism, it's
sometimes referred to as reality, which is what,
in yoga, the eighth limb of Samadhi, which is
really that union with really unity consciousness,
or some might say the union with the divine of
dialing into the information that we can access
when we focus. You mentioned Dean Radin, and I
know in his information that he's put forth that
he talks about, from his book, Real Magic, when
he studied how people are able to be really good
manifestors, if you will, in life, or create
something that they want to create, is that
intention, attention, so that focus, and then
also the feeling of that desire of what you want
can assist in that regard. Have you found that in your experiences in remote viewing?
Absolutely. Not just remote viewing, but the
capacity to manifest, I think is what you're
talking about. You have an image of something you
want to create, and if you focus on that image and
also then let it go, if you keep holding it,
then it just... But if you can incorporate it,
and I think even in the words of Jesus, or somewhere in the Bible, it said,
feel as if it has already happened. So if
you want something, if you focus on the want,
all you're going to get is want. Now, I didn't
realize that until I realized that's what I was
doing. I wanted something, and it's like, oh. But
by focusing, and I think Einstein even says it,
it's like physics, focus on having, then you
put the having in the field, because the field
of intention, if you want to call it that, I think
Joseph, what's his name? Joe Dispenza calls it
the quantum field, and other people do too.
If you put the feeling into the quantum field,
it's malleable, right? So the intent and incorporating the having as if it is,
I mean, it's what's behind that movie, The
Secret. The secret is having, and then having
what you've had, but the feeling of it will generate the actual manifestation of that.
Well, I feel like we're talking about receiving
information, and then also creating what we want,
and I think that those can go hand in hand. So just staying with receiving information
or consciousness, it sounds like we are exploring, how does that happen?
And so how do you think that happens, Alan?
Well, that's the question I've been trying to,
thank you for asking that, because that's been
my search ever since I realized, not just for me,
but thousands, and of course, there's people a
lot better remote viewers than me, they develop
a facility, and everyone can remote view, of
course, some people, everyone can play the piano,
everyone can take a picture, it's just some people have a natural facility for that.
So I found just in my own example, in my own
case, it's like, okay, I'm getting an image
that my intent is a target. And it feels like, if you're not really subtly,
kind of pulling apart the application of consciousness, it feels like you're making
it up. So I tell people even in teaching remote
viewing, let the image come, and know it's not
your imagination. Because, but it feels like,
oh, no, we're getting thoughts all day long.
Some of them are remote views, some of them,
some of it's just fantasy, imagination,
or creating, and it's hard to know the difference
between that. But when you start to develop the
facility for remote viewing, you'd start to
distinguish, and this is the hardest part of
remote viewing, what is your own stuff, you know,
what Russell Targ said, what's the difference
between the noise that's always going on in your
head and the signal. And he says it's that piece,
and this was so key when I learned it, the
unexpected ideas or images that come to your
mind. So when things just pop in, because you
want to be as empty as possible, it pops in,
and you have to know it's not your imagination.
And with enough practice, and this is like why
feedback is so important within, you know,
with psychics and remote viewing that, yeah,
when you get the feedback, you can see, oh, I
got this, but then I made an analytical overlay
where I made an association immediately to say, oh, it must be this.
So one theory is we have to be in right brain
awareness, which is different than left brain
awareness. Left brain is comprehension. Right
brain is apprehension. So we're apprehending
the target. As soon as you say, I know what it is,
you're immediately wrong, unless you're really a
great remote viewer and you've really trained.
So if the left brain doesn't know anything,
it just thinks it does. That's my theory. So the
idea is that the right brain is the intuitive,
creative, and a lot of remote viewers recommend
a book called Drawing on the Right Side of Your
Brain, which really develops the capacity for
intuitive thoughts and feelings that are coming
from nowhere. But just saying it's right brain
may localize it or identify it, like Stuart
Hameroff says it's the microtubules, or other
people say it's part of the hippocampus.
But anyway, what's going on is that, so you think
it's imaginary, right? I mean, because you're
getting these images that come into your minds,
but I say it's imaginal. I say it's actually a
cognition. So it's like we cognize things with
our five senses and our intellect, but my theory
is like, we're perceiving, I call it seeing the
dark when I teach remotely, because we're actually
cognizing input of non-local sensing capacities
of consciousness. Does that make sense?
Mm-hmm.
So I wanted to understand what does that mean, the cognition, and I looked all over,
and I didn't find anything to really explain that
until I came across the work of Henry Corbin,
who was a translator of Middle Eastern texts
and documents. And I don't know why I was even
reading this, but he, in one of his documents,
said that when he's very advanced spiritual
concepts of these, particularly of Sufis, Henry Corbin said, the imaginal cognition,
which is what I'm calling the application that remote viewing does in telepathy,
is actually you're tapping into a whole other
realm, something that's purely immaterial
beyond the realm of the body and mind, I mean,
the logical mind. So when you're remote viewing,
some people say you're not actually going everywhere, because if consciousness is
non-local, consciousness is everywhere, and
we're remote viewing everywhere all at once,
because that consciousness that we think is
local is really tapped into all time and space.
So if we follow that understanding of imaginal,
then I'll get to some of the other work of Henry
Corbin and how we discovered this translating
these ancient spiritual texts. And he says,
I found it impossible to content myself with the word imaginary that these great
masters were talking about, because imaginary
equates to the unreal or a fantasy. And the reason
I absolutely had to find another expression was
that my profession as an interpreter of Arabic
and Sufi and spiritual texts would have betrayed
those texts if I simply used the word imaginary.
So he basically created this word, maybe other
people had called it something before, imaginal.
And this imaginal capacity that every human being
has in dreams, in visions, in telepathic messages,
it's a receiving by the brain. So he said, I
called this imaginal cognition, which is tapping
into a realm that actually, he says, survives
the body and mind. So when you're remote viewing,
it's like, and this is how I understand it,
Plato talks about the ideal aspects of things,
the platonic forms was the, let's even say,
the morphogenetic field of a thing that exists
beyond the thing. When we're using imaginal
cognition, we're remote viewing something in time
and space, but it's also something that exists
in this imaginal realm beyond time and space.
The object in time and space, this is my theory, and maybe someone agrees with it,
it's a shadow of the imaginal realms. So when
we're dreaming, we're more in the imaginal realms
than this world, we're swimming through this
other realm that's beyond the mind, the intellect,
but we're accessing something that actually is
a world, this is my feeling. So he also says,
I'm just quoting Henry Corbin, it must be stressed
that this world is perfectly real. And this,
of course, is just his theory, but it seems to resonate with what I was looking for.
How could I have cognition of something that
wasn't local, and people are doing it all the
time, remote viewing. So it's just a name,
it doesn't mean anything, just names put our
placeholder for explanations, and this really
makes sense to me about understanding remote
viewing. So he says, this imaginal reality is
irrefutable and more coherent than the empirical
world perceived by our senses, yet we don't know how to get to that. We stumble upon it
in remote viewing. So Corbin says, by developing our imaginal perceptions,
we go beyond the intellectual mind and develop a
new sense to directly perceive a super sensible
reality, a super sensible reality. And one more
aspect is he's not really the first one to talk
about this. I mean, he may have named it, but
Rudolf Steiner says this, he called it the
imaginative cognition. And Rudolf Steiner in
the 1920s and 30s, the only reason this realm
of cognition remains unfamiliar is because we
consider this form, all other forms other than
five senses, impossible to cognize. But it is
possible to develop another form of cognition
that leads to the super sensible world. This
is Rudolf Steiner says it. And he may have been
influenced by the Swedish mystic, Swedenborg,
who says that all progressions in the spiritual
world are affected by changes in states of consciousness. He says, therefore, there's
really no difference if you're near or far from picking up these vibrational energies,
called the vibrational energy. One more reference,
and then I'd love you to jump in is Carl Jung.
He says, he called it the act of imagination
is a perception. So he calls the imaginal what
the act of imagination, other people call it
the imaginal, what did Steiner call it there?
No, he called it the imaginative cognition. I
think the most way of framing it is imaginal,
because it's imagined, it's not quite imagined,
and it's not quite made up, it's perceived.
But Jung says this can be accessed through
automatic writing, artistic creation, dance,
music, probably if he was aware of channeling,
he would do called channeling. So that sort of
is my thesis of naming things, how that works
is sort of an extension of this. But does that
make sense that I'm calling this realm of
consciousness that accesses the non-local field,
imaginal, and it's just a name?
How does that relate then to our own
consciousness? You're suggesting that this imaginal
realm is something we can access when we get out
of our own way with like thinking about what we're
going to have for dinner or worrying about how
we're going to pay a certain bill or wondering
what we're going to do the following weekend.
You're suggesting that we can drop into this
aspect of our consciousness?
Yeah, it is an aspect, exactly. It's an aspect
of consciousness, the stuff you're talking about,
like what are you going to have for dinner? Who
should I call? That's the ego mind. That's left
brain ego mind sense of individualized self. And
that's one aspect of consciousness. It's the local
aspect. The imaginal is when you drop away from
the self, the small self, and allow the vastness,
and we talked about human potential that we're coming into as a spiritual culture,
things that Thinking Allowed has talked about
for 40 years, this spiritualization of humanity,
at least in the Western world. I mean, the
indigenous has already had that and never lost
it. But in the Western world, the sense that
spirit is a vital part of who we are and not
reduced to biology, which some people do. But
with Richard Dawkins, it's all in your mind.
And my mother, for that matter, says, dead is
dead. So that's our truth. And so it's not.
I think if we've had a sense, even remotely,
if you said the little out-of-body experience,
if you even met a near-death experience or have
had that yourself, there's no doubt when I read
Anita Moorjani's book, that this woman was the
real thing. And other people too. And my own
out-of-body experiences and past life. So the incorporation of spirit, of qualities,
which means essentially that we're eternal,
this other facility of, okay, if we're eternal,
what's the cognitive faculty of this eternal sense
of self? That's where I was really kind of...
And it's a hypothesis. There's no way to prove
this. We're just using words to name things. But
there is work by, you mentioned Stuart Hameroff, that the microtubules may be the
containers of consciousness. But even saying that,
how do we define something that can't be put
into a box? If consciousness is non-local,
and we have a facility or an application,
because people are into apps, to perceive that,
at least that gives us a sense of our own immortal nature.
I think I'll write a book called How the CIA Discovered Divinity. Because really,
it's through the workings and the funding of the
CIA that Stanford Research Institute was able to
go so deep into the proof that non-local awareness is absolutely a fact.
I mean, there's only arguments about that if you haven't studied it.
People will argue all the time, like, no, that's
impossible until you do it yourself or see
an infinite amount of experiments that have
proven, when Ingo Swann remote viewed Jupiter
and said, oh, there's a ring around Jupiter. And
they said, oh, you must be looking at Saturn.
Ingo said, I've been looking at the solar system
my whole life. I know the difference between
Saturn and Jupiter, believe me. I see a ring
around. And maybe five or 10 years later,
they discovered there was this ring around
Jupiter. So we have to trust and we have to use
this application for our advantage. So if I go
out to a restaurant, I try a remote view. Okay,
if I eat this food, how will my body feel later
on? And sometimes I override it, like if I want
ice cream or something like that. So, oh, it'll
feel so good now. And I just disconnect from
remote viewing. When do I want to feel good? Do I want to feel good now or later?
That's right. That's right. And it's always good
to preserve. Yeah, I mean, it does feel great,
but you know, so this has practical application. It's very true.
I just wanted to bring up in my search for understanding what exactly I was teaching
people in remote viewing. I teach about
every few months on lightnet.org, Zenka Caro
kind of understanding how to not just remote
view, but do what the government is actually
doing now, remote view with what's out there,
their UFOs, other planets. Of course, there's
no way to get feedback about that. But I think
my theory about that is if enough people can
remote view a target and get an agreement, like,
okay, we all remote view this target I have,
and everyone says, wow, that's the Eiffel Tower
there. And or not even name it, but some image.
If we can get an agreement about that, then let's
remote view a place that we don't, we can't prove
and see if there's an agreement upon that.
Of course, I talked to Paul Smith about that.
And he says, well, you might be getting a
telepathic overlay, like someone has a strong
idea about something and everyone picks up on that
telepathic overlay that's being projected there.
So that might be true. That might be true.
So anyway, it's just my search to understand
what is the mechanism of the mind?
How do you think this imaginal realm, imaginal cognition connects with intuition?
It's the same thing. It's really the same thing.
Intuition is an aspect of that imaginal realm
that's there. It's like, what aspect of that
facility are you using? What part of, let's say,
Facebook are you using? Are you just looking at
people's photos? Are you looking up information?
It's like, how are you using the app? And I think
if you have intuition, if you have telepathy,
it may not be the exact same thing as remote
viewing. But it's pretty much you've opened that
door to the imaginal. So imaginal includes, to me,
I don't know if Henry Corbin, if he was around,
would still agree with that. But he just has a new
book out. Someone told me something coming up. I
definitely want to get a book about his work and
how it's really, when I read that work of Henry
Corbin, it really defined the nature of non-local
reality. It's really, for me, the landscape of
non-local reality. But what that doesn't do
is still explain the physiological mechanisms
of how that works. Where's the antenna? Where in our mind, and of course, you said,
maybe it's in every cell of our body, right?
Well, that's when I interviewed Dr. Thomas
Verny. He spent, I believe, seven years researching thousands. I think it was like
5,000 books and papers on consciousness and
cellular awareness and memory. And he basically
came to the conclusion that consciousness is in every cell and every aspect, really,
maybe even down to a holographic level, infinitesimally. Then it also then begs the
question of how or why are we here? How are we able to talk to each other? We eat food,
we drink, we sleep, but we're getting energy
from somewhere. And then there's also what
all the world's, most of the wisdom and spiritual traditions talk about,
that everything is interconnected. To prove
that point, that consciousness is in every cell,
there's a book called The Heart's Code, where,
what was his name, Pearsall, talks about a heart
transplant. Yes. You know about that. It was given
to, of a girl that was murdered into another young
girl, and that young girl who was the recipient
from the donor who was killed was able to identify
the person who did that act to that. And also
people who had liver transplants or even lung
or heart, take on a persona or aspects of the
persona of the donor. So there is something
about lineage, and we can't escape our parents.
Somehow we're the recipients of all those thought
form realities that we're trying to undo and
work through, but it's genetically passed down.
That's why blood is such a powerful agent,
because something of that is transmitted, I think,
in the DNA, in the cells, in the body, in the
fluids that is of the essence of that spirit.
So you say, how is it that we eat? I think we're not a closed system. We're getting
downloads, energy that is beyond food. It's maybe coming up from the earth itself,
but we're being fed by an infinite source, which
is our connection to spirit. And I think it's
our connection to the imaginal realm is feeding
us too, because I find when I go to sleep,
if I'm tired and just get a little bit of sleep
and start a sense of dreaming, I'm energized.
So there's something about visiting that, what
I'm calling the imaginal world. It's an aspect
of the dream world as well. And it may be deep
into the territory of the imaginal. Maybe when
you're just remote viewing, you're stepping your
toe in it, but when you're dreaming and you're
consumed by that world, you're in the imaginal or an aspect of that.
And I think they're real worlds. I mean, I think dreams might actually be
more real than this world we think is real. And
that's also goes into where maybe there was an
interface when the imaginal realms and maybe
there's places on the earth, which are more
intersecting with this reality. Maybe that's how
you explain dragons and fairies and elves and
angels because, and vortex points that intersect
to these realms that open up a little doorway
to this other realm that is most likely real. But if you're really hardcore,
you know, Western, you don't think anything
beyond the five senses exists. And this is the
huge transformation that allows thinking to perceive in uncharted ways.
Going back to what you were saying earlier about, how is it that some people are more
skilled at this? So you suggest that, of
course, you've mentioned some of the greatest,
well-known remote viewers on the planet at the moment. It seems that perhaps
karma might play a role as far as what a
person might be literally attuned to perceive.
Well, that's one aspect of it, just like long fingers make a better piano player,
because maybe you also learned in a past life how
to play the piano or something. But what Garry
Nolan of Stanford University and Kit Green, who
was, I would say, a renegade investigator for this
government, discovered that remote viewers actually have more developed parts of the
hypothalamus they call the pucate and the caudate. It's like these Latin frames that
are white matter that are near the hypothalamus
that seem to need more developed in remote viewers
and experiences. They discovered, wow, this is an abnormality originally thought,
but they discovered, well, these people don't
exhibit abnormal behavior, they actually exhibit
supernormal behavior, supernormal attributes.
So the question that I don't think has been
investigated, did that white matter expand, was
that genetically related or did it expand because
they were actually developing that through remote
viewing? Or is that a natural process that makes
people naturally remote viewers? So I think experiments could be done where you take
someone who's never remote viewed and you develop
that and do MRIs and see if that really affects
the tissue. Or like experiencers, it's hard
to know when someone's an experiencer of UFOs,
but it's definitely, and Whitley Strieber has
talked about this too, that his areas of the
brain were much more developed in that area because he's probably one of the most,
I would say, experienced experiencers, but he is, he's one of the most lucid
experiencers I've ever met. So that would be something, so maybe I'm thinking
not so much the microtubules, which of course may
be in every cell, which are in every cell that pick
the emanations of spirits. So I think those
microtubules are maybe what Bruce Lipton calls
self-receptors. Self-receptors, maybe it's not
exactly, he says that receives a signal of self.
So when someone has a heart, liver, lung transplant, the natural body reactions of
the self-receptors push against that, but there's drugs they take that suppress the
self-receptors. So maybe that's why the aspects of the donor are put into the body.
I think the self-receptors may be the antenna
to spirit that allows us to incarnate,
in form, and bring in this non-local consciousness
